Quicksort

C.A.R. Hoare paper

Worst-case: $\Theta(n^2)$
Average-case: $\Theta(n \log n)$--best comparison-based runtime for sort

Design: divide-and-conquer paradigm
Divide: Partition by choice of partition point $q$ : $A[p \dots r] = A[p \dots q-1] + A[q+1 \dots r]$
Conquer: Sort by recursive calls to quicksort
Combine: Done in place

Partitioning:
Maintain the following loop invariants
$A[p \dots i] \le x$
$A[i+1 \dots j] \gt x$
$A[j+1 \dots r]$ are unseen

Recursively partitioning finishes the sort

Runtime depends on good partitioning
Worst-case (Unbalanced)
    Gives one piece empty and the other of size $n-1$, which occurs when pivot $\ge$ then everything or $\lt$ everything
